intro: Lomatia fallacina, commonly known as the mistletoe of the genus Lomatia, is a hemiparasitic plant native to southeastern Australia. It grows on the branches of eucalyptus and other host trees, deriving some of its nutrients from the host while also performing photosynthesis. Its leaves are small, oval, and often covered in fine hairs, and its flowers are white or pale green, typically arranged in clusters. The plant produces small, red berries that are an important food source for birds. Due to its restricted distribution and ecological significance, it is considered a rare and vulnerable species.
